newsitem.title: USA: GM WANTS FASTER DEVELOPMENTS FROM SUPPLIERS.
newsitem.headline: GM WANTS FASTER DEVELOPMENTS FROM SUPPLIERS.

text.p: General Motors Corp's top purchasing executive urged suppliers at an automotive conference Friday to cut in half the time it takes to develop new technologies.
"Where process time can be reduced, reduce it," Harold Kutner vice president of worldwide purchasing said in remarks prepared for delivery.
"And I don't mean shave a second here or there. Look for quantum reductions of 10, 20, even 50 percent," he said.
Kutner spoke on the final day of the University of Michigan's week-long Management Briefing Seminar.
Kutner said GM spends about $70 billion a year to buy components and systems for the 8.3 million vehicles it makes in 25 countries.

GM has angered suppliers in the past by demanding price cuts. But Kutner said the automaker is improving its relations. He pointed to an annual survey from Ward's Auto World, a trade publication, which showed 32 percent of the survey's respondents chose GM as one of the best automakers to work with.
The results show GM's global supplier process is working, Kutner said, as evidenced by the growing number of contracts GM is awarding in Latin America and Asia/Pacific.

GM's worldwide purchasing operations are structured into four groups around the world, Europe, Latin America, Asia/Pacific and North America. The regions are designed to simplify purchasing decisions and help suppliers become part of GM's international sourcing network

In Latin America, where GM has 21 percent market share, the company is buidling new facilities, including a new stamping plant in Brazil, a manufacturing facility in Argentina and new paint shops in Argentina and Venezuela.
Those investments have resulted in 40 new international suppliers starting operations, representing more than $380 million in purchases from GM.

GM's Asia/Pacific group have helped 30 global suppliers set up facilities in Thailand to provide parts for a new vehicle program that will reach more than $600 million a year, Kutner said. GM has a goal in Thailand of sourcing 60 percent of its parts locally.
